chargeHist.descr: Throw/Discharge Bodily Fluid at Public Safety Worker or Prosecutor

result.execSummary:
Charge(s) in this case were read in to this or other case(s). A "read in" charge is a charge that is dismissed as part of a plea agreement, however:

  • The defendant agrees to have the court consider the charge(s) when sentencing for another crime, under Wis. Stats. 973.20(1g)(b); and
  • The defendant cannot be prosecuted for these charge(s) in the future.

On one or more charges in this case, Dominic J Aversa was found not guilty by reason of mental disease or defect. The defendant was found guilty of actually committing the crime(s) charged, but was also found not to be legally responsible under Wis. Stats. 971.165 for committing the crime(s) because of the defendant's mental condition. The legal effect of a finding of not guilty by reason of mental disease or defect is that the court must commit the defendant to the custody of the Department of Health and Family Services.

Notice to employers: It may be a violation of state law to discriminate against a job applicant because of an arrest or conviction record. Generally speaking, an employer may refuse to hire an applicant on the basis of a conviction only if the circumstances of the conviction substantially relate to the particular job. For more information, see Wisconsin Statute 111.335 and the Department of Workforce Development's publication, Arrest and Conviction Records under the Law.

10:28 AM 21CF378, 21CF408, 22CF39. Defendant Dominic J Aversa in court, in custody of OZSD.  Attorney Rachel Marie Boaz in court for Dominic J Aversa. Adam Gerol appears for the State of Wisconsin.  Also present in court is pre-dispositional order writer Debra Wagner. Pre-dispositional report on file. Defense has no objection. Relating to all cases, State requesting 7 1/2 year commitment as an inpatient.  Defense requesting 4 1/2 year inpatient treatment.  Court gives order.
Predisposition Investigation Report.  Forwarded as document for review to Branch 3 clerk .
for Predisposition Investigation (Not Guilty by Reason of Mental Disease or Defect).  Forwarded to DHS.
Forwarded to DHS.
Hearing on July 18, 2022 at 10:00 am.

1:24 PM  Cases 21CF378, 21CF408, 22CF38, and 22CF39 called. Prosecuting attorney Benjamin Lindsay in court for the State of Wisconsin.  Defendant Dominic J Aversa in court, in custody.  Attorney Rachel Marie Boaz in court for Dominic J Aversa. Plea questionnaire on file.  State gives recommendation of 7 1/2 years commitment relating to all cases.  Defendant enters special plea. Court examines defendant, accepts plea and finds defendant guilty but not guilty by mental disease or defect. Based on Dr. Collin's report the court finds at the time of the offenses, to the charges defendant has now plead guilty too, Defendant was not able to conform to the law due to mental disease.  Court orders an investigation order pursuant to 971.17(2)(a). An initial commitment is ordered at this time and upon review matter can be revisited. Statement given by victim who is present in court.  Next hearing scheduled for July 18, 2022 at 10:00 am.
Plea/sentencing hearing on June 1, 2022 at 01:30 pm.

1:20 PM  (Cases called 21CF378; 21CF408; 22CF38; 22CF39)Prosecuting attorney Adam Yale Gerol appeared in court for the State of Wisconsin, Defendant Dominic J Aversa appeared in court, in custody, telephonically from Winnebago Mental Health Institution, Attorney Rachel Marie Boaz appeared in court for Dominic J Aversa. Counsel and District Atty in receipt of the doctor's report. Defendant was found to be competent and there is no objection by Atty Boaz for the court to receive the report into evidence. Defense will not be contesting determination. State requests the court make finding of competency with no other testimony or evidence. Court gives finding that the defendant is competent.
